Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(2) Summary

An API platform is whatever your organization has in place to support API providers and API consumers. API platforms should be able to adjust to changing contexts and needs, and in order to do that they must be designed to be open and extensible. We take a look at why and how companies should open up their API platforms, and present four indicators to assess and guide your journey towards an open API platform. These open API platforms then can serve as a stable and yet constantly changing foundation for an organization's evolving API landscape.

Understanding Platforms

Outline (Understanding Platforms)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. Understanding Platforms [9]

Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(7) Two Perspectives on APIs

  1. APIs help to move away from monolithic application architectures
    • Moving towards loose coupling to allow for more IT agility
    • Separating implementations (microservices) for faster deployment
  2. APIs are the connective fabric of digital transformation
    • Partner and public APIs allow to move towards the API economy
    • Private APIs allow for easier ways to develop and test new value chains
  • APIs can do both of these things
    • IT modernization is often necessary to improve speed and safety of IT
    • Enterprise architecture then can build new IT-aligned business models


Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(8) The World is Changing Faster

  • Existing value chains may be challenged and must adapt
  • Global connectivity enables new opportunities to scale
  • A networked economy creates many network effects
  • Changing markets require changes in products and value propositions


Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(9) Linear Business Models



Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(10) Platforms are Eating the World

  • Platforms businesses are taking over many markets
  • Platforms facilitate value exchanges
  • Platforms scale well
  • Platforms are using the network effect
  • Platforms are a lesson in thinking beyond the linear model


Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(11) The Platform Business Model



Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(12) Platform Types

  • Platform business models come in two flavors
  • Exchange platforms facilitate exchanges of existing value
    • Value is transferred and often limited in supply by producers
    • The core transaction often has to be made as frictionless as possible
  • Maker platforms support creation of value on the platform
    • Value is exposed and often unlimited in supply
    • The core transaction often is designed to improve value creation/consumption


Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(13) But … We're not Google

  • Pure platforms are more the exception than the norm
  • Linear business models can be augmented with platform ideas
  • Creating hybrid models can make a big difference
    • Opportunity to scale because the platform part attracts consumers
    • Ability to differentiate in an increasingly commoditized market
    • Decreasing risk because of more feedback and ability to adapt


Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(14) Hybrid Linear/Platform Business Models



Understanding Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(15) A Cautionary Tale

  • Many organizations are adding social features to their products/experiences
  • Protecting against trolling, spam, and harassment is important
  • Building robust social protections is not trivial
  • Organizations end up with dependencies in their value chains


Open Everything

Open Everything Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(17) Growing the Foundation

  • API First [https://www.apiscene.io/api-business-models/api-first-the-essence-of-digital-transformation/] means to embrace APIs as the organization's business language
  • API First means making all assets/services available as APIs
    1. Expose existing/new assets and capabilities to the platform
    2. Add existing/new experiences to the platform
  • API First builds on the network effect [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_effect] of organizational capabilities
    1. Adding APIs as a way to support value co-creation


Open Everything Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(18) Unlock Existing Value: Open Everything



Open Everything Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(19) This is how we do things around here.

  • This is how we do things around here.
    • Document practices as well as what they address and why that's necessary
  • This is how we do things around here.
    • Practices may involve building blocks and tooling
  • This is how we do things around here.
    • Culture emerges from practice instead of being top-down
  • This is how we do things around here.
    • Different communities or practices can exist and co-exist

(21) API Guidelines in the Wild



Open Everything Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(22) Open API Landscapes

  • Organic API landscapes evolve over time
  • Adjust guidance to changing practices and patterns
  • Support different deployment models (on-premise, cloud, multi-cloud)
  • Look for API pains and address the biggest ones


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. Understanding Platforms [9]
  3. Open Everything [6]
  4. Conclusions [2]
Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How

(24) Platformize Yourself

  • Consider new value chains based on platform business models
  • Open and evolve your platform to open everything that you have
  • Build everything to become part of your platform
  • Always consider the cost of change and design/build for change


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Opening up Your API Platform: Why and How
